Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: End-To-End Test Data Analytics For Automotive Chip Production Lines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Using automotive industry as the research driver, this project aims to develop novel data mining solutions to address the challenge of reliable low-power, high quality chip production by improving the effectiveness and reducing the cost of testing them. While research in the data mining community focuses more on developing generic approaches, this project focuses on developing dedicated approaches, optimized for mining test measurement data. The techniques developed in this project can complement and bring synergies to existing data mining research. The technologies developed through this project will be transferred to the industry, providing solutions to overcome the challenges in the automotive chip sector. Furthermore, the research will be integrated with educational activities to produce publications, curriculum materials, tutorials, and software tools for broader impacts to the semiconductor industry.

In production, automotive chip products go through a rather comprehensive test process to assure their quality. End-to-end test data refers to all data collected in this process which comprises multiple stages, starting from product manufacturing all the way to evaluation in an electronic system. Analytics refers to the discovery, interpretation, and utilization of knowledge extracted from the data. This research aims to enable effective and robust analytics in order to improve product quality and reduce production test cost. For effectiveness, novel software tools and methodologies will be designed to automatically incorporate domain knowledge in the analytics. For robustness, new approaches will be developed to determine the meaningfulness of data mining results. From a practical perspective, solutions developed through the research will benefit the semiconductor industry by facilitating the effective use of large-scale data mining for test process optimization. From a scientific perspective, this research will provide a deeper understanding of the limitations with test data analytics and enable its robust implementation. Overall, this project aims to develop the next-generation test data analytics software, thereby enabling application of the research to diverse scenarios encountered in semiconductor chip production test environments.

ProgramReference.Text: DES AUTO FOR MICRO & NANO SYST

POR.DRECONTENT:
In semiconductor testing process, tremendous amounts of data are generated. Analysis of these data has been a common practice in the industry for decades. Test data analytics is an integral part of the production operation, for improving the yield, reducing the test cost, and assuring the quality of the products shipped to the customer. Majority of the analytics practices today rely on workflows that involve manual inspection of the data. With recent advances in machine learning, there are growing interests to apply machine learning in test data analytics to automate the analytics workflows. This project was proposed to develop an automatic end-to-end solution for test data analytics. For developing the solution, the project also aimed to employ modern machine learning techniques whenever they were applicable.

In the project, multiple novel methods are developed to enable realization of an end-to-end test data analytics solution. More importantly, a software framework is developed to facilitate utilization of modern machine learning into a test data analytics workflow. In view of how an engineer would manually inspect the data in practice, a novel plot-based analytics approach is developed to automate the manual inspection. In plot-based analytics, the input is a large pool of plots derived from the data. The output is those selected few plots representing the analytics result. In plot-based analytics, the essential component is a library of so-called concept recognizers. Each recognizer is for recognizing a particular class of plots where its semantic meaning is determined by the workflow. In essence, concept recognizers intend to capture an engineer?s perception involved in executing an analytics workflow.

In the software framework, machine learning techniques are applied to learn concept recognizers from plot samples. However, unlike that in traditional machine learning where a large number of samples are usually available for a class, for learning a concept recognizer, very often only a few plot samples are available. In some situations, a concept is represented by only one sample. In addition to these challenges, plot-based analytics also needs to support online batch processing where a collection of plots is provided without labels. Batch processing automatically determines if there is a new concept to learn and if yes, extracts the training samples for learning the concept recognizer. Throughout the research, innovative approaches were developed to enable automatic learning of a concept recognizer. In particular, a novel method based on tensor computation techniques was developed to provide the batch processing capability. Two novel methods were developed for learning a concept recognizer. The first method supports the learning with a minimal of five plot samples. The underlying technology for implementing the method is based on Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). The second method supports generation of additional samples based on a given plot sample. The method is based on a novel approach called manifestation learning which can be considered as a form of transfer learning. The underlying technology for implementing the method is based on Variational Autoencoder (VAE).

Because a concept recognizer is a neural network model, it is difficult to guarantee that it does not make a mistake in its recognition. Once deployed, a concept recognizer monitors the data stream from a production line. If there is a deficiency in the recognition, it is desirable to flag a warning as soon as possible. To achieve this capability, another type of monitor is needed to check the performance of a concept recognizer online. In the research, a novel method was developed to achieve this online checking capability. The method is based on tensor computation techniques to build a tensor-based recognizer which performs recognition in parallel to the neural network recognizer. Then, the method compares the result from the two recognizers to determine if there is a deficiency.   

The practical impacts of the research are demonstrated through extensive experiments based on test data from actual production lines. Graduate students involved in the research have done multiple internships in the industry to facilitate technology transfer of our research results. While the plot-based analytics approach is developed specifically for the types of plots commonly seen in test data analytics, the approach and its associated methods can be generalized to a variety of other types of plots and provide a new direction for achieving prescriptive analytics in general. The workflow-driven plot-based analytics software framework developed through the research provides a defined platform to apply modern machine learning in test data analytics, which can be extended to automate a wide variety of analytics tasks in a semiconductor production flow. Furthermore, on the subject of applying machine learning in the semiconductor field, findings from the research enable the development of new courses for undergraduate and graduate students as well as tutorials for industrial practitioners, which prepare them with skills to better meet the current and future demands in the industry.


Last Modified: 09/28/2020
Modified by: Li-Chung Wang
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In semiconductor testing process, tremendous amounts of data are generated. Analysis of these data has been a common practice in the industry for decades. Test data analytics is an integral part of the production operation, for improving the yield, reducing the test cost, and assuring the quality of the products shipped to the customer. Majority of the analytics practices today rely on workflows that involve manual inspection of the data. With recent advances in machine learning, there are growing interests to apply machine learning in test data analytics to automate the analytics workflows. This project was proposed to develop an automatic end-to-end solution for test data analytics. For developing the solution, the project also aimed to employ modern machine learning techniques whenever they were applicable. In the project, multiple novel methods are developed to enable realization of an end-to-end test data analytics solution. More importantly, a software framework is developed to facilitate utilization of modern machine learning into a test data analytics workflow. In view of how an engineer would manually inspect the data in practice, a novel plot-based analytics approach is developed to automate the manual inspection. In plot-based analytics, the essential component is a library of so-called concept recognizers. The workflow-driven plot-based analytics software framework developed through the research provides a defined platform to apply modern machine learning in test data analytics, which can be extended to automate a wide variety of analytics tasks in a semiconductor production flow. Furthermore, on the subject of applying machine learning in the semiconductor field, findings from the research enable the development of new courses for undergraduate and graduate students as well as tutorials for industrial practitioners, which prepare them with skills to better meet the current and future demands in the industry.
